ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course helped reinforce and elevate my Spanish speaking, writing, and reading skills.
In this course, I had a lot of practice speaking, reading, and writing in Spanish. I gained confidence in my skills.
I learned grammar and vocabulary at the Intermediate Spanish speaking/reading/writing level.
I learned how to clearly talk and write in Spanish and how to continue a conversation smoothly.

My Spanish skills improved immensely. The biggest improvement, I think, was my grammar. It really gets drilled into you by all the homework and practice, and the end result is that you learn a lot. I also got better at speaking and writing fluently.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength would be the repetition and immersion of the class in that it makes you really think in Spanish. I also really enjoyed the tie-ins with Spanish culture, such as the movies, short stories, and novels we read. Perhaps one weakness is that many of the major assignments were often clustered together and it sometimes felt there wasn't enough room to breathe in between.

I felt this class really does force you to learn Spanish, but the amount of work, even for a 1.5 credit course seemed excessive, even unnecessary, especially considering we were learning in a fully virtual/stressful covid semester.
The course did a great job adjusting to COVID. I really liked the assignments as it had a great variety and the conversations in class were fun.

Strengths: a wonderful professor. Very kind and responsive, and she cares a lot. Also your Spanish skills really do improve quite a bit.

Weaknesses: the virtual format meant that it was harder to get to know people and build a community, although I think we did about as well as we could have given the circumstances.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought giving Tuesdays and Thursdays off as asynchronous was very helpful in giving me extra time to do the work and practice more.
I felt having class only 3 days a week instead of most days (sometimes it would be 4 days, with virtual live class on either Tuesday or Thursday) really helped with fighting off zoom fatigue.
This class was the best class for me at adjusting to the new circumstances.
The professor did a good job making use of the Zoom chat during lessons, which I thought was smart.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course because it really does help improve your Spanish skills over the course of the term, and I definitely gained confidence in my own Spanish-speaking abilities after taking this course. The feedback is also helpful, such as feedback from your compositions.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in Spanish or need to fulfill the language requirement.
I would only recommend this course to someone that has to take this class for their language requirement or wants to get a very intensive course in intermediate Spanish.
I would recommend this course because it improves your speaking and writing and the assignments are fun.

Yes I would recommend this course, for a few reasons. First, you really do improve your Spanish skills quite a bit. I went into the class without a very expert knowledge of grammar, and by the end I knew a ton more. Second, although this class has a decent amount of work, grading is very fair (and your grade seems to get better as the semester goes on, probably because you're improving, so don't be intimidated at first). There are a lot of assignments, tests and quizzes, but not an overwhelming amount, and this made it so that your entire grade isn't riding on one test grade, which is nice. Lastly, and maybe most importantly, Prof. Cividanes is absolutely excellent. She will make you work hard, but she is incredibly kind and understanding, and you can tell how much she cares about the class and her students. If you are taking Spanish, please choose Prof. Cividanes! You won't regret it.
